questions.text: A 24-year-old man who presented with hepatomegaly and neuropsychiatric symptoms is found to have the following picture on ophthalmic examination. You suspect Wilson's disease. Which of the following is the gold standard for the clinical diagnosis of Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
The gold standard for the clinical diagnosis of Wilson's disease is liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays. The affected patients have values >3.1 μmol/g (>200 μg/g (dry weight) of liver). 

The urinary copper level is an important diagnostic tool and symptomatic patients have copper levels >1.6 μmol (>100 μg) per 24 hour.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause?
questions.solution:
Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.

Postmenopausal bleeding is defined as bleeding from the genital tract, more than 12 months after the last menstrual period in a woman not on hormone replacement. All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial malignancy since age is a significant risk factor for this.

Transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) is a better first-line investigation since TVS is not included in the options, endometrial sampling is the next best answer.

Endometrial sampling is indicated if:

  • The endometrial thickness is >4 mm
  • The endometrium shows diffuse or focal increased echogenicity (heterogeneity)
  • The endometrium is not adequately visualized on transvaginal sonography
  • The woman has persistent bleeding, as it can be a sign of endometrial cancer even when the endometrial thickness is less than 4mm.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

 

Other options:

Option A: Pap smear should be offered to all women above the age of 21 years who are sexually active for at least 3 years. Colposcopic examination and selective biopsy are considered in patients with abnormal Pap smears.

Option B: Visual inspection with iodine is done where the facilities for Pap screening do not exist. This involves painting the cervix with Lugol's iodine. It is used to detect any abnormal cytology in the cervix and vagina, such as in cases of carcinoma cervix.

The normal vaginal and cervical epithelium contains glycogen, therefore stains mahogany brown on being painted with Lugol's iodine. The abnormal cells remain unstained. These areas need to be biopsied and sent for histopathological examination.

Option C: The colposcopic study is challenging in postmenopausal women because of narrow vaginas, senile vaginitis, indrawn and poorly visible squamocolumnar junction, and atrophic cervix.

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
In a bedridden patient presenting with sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain, there is a concern for possible pulmonary embolism (PE). Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can be suspected in this patient because of his bedridden status. The screening test used for DVT is the D-dimer measurement.

DVT of the leg is complicated by the immediate risk of pulmonary embolus and sudden death. Patients are at risk of developing a post-thrombotic limb and venous ulceration. 

Virchow's Triad: three factors important in the development of venous thrombosis. 

  • Endothelial injury (vascular Injury)
  • Hypercoagulability of blood
  • Stasia or turbulence of blood flow

The most important predisposing factor is hospital admissions for the treatment of a medical or surgical condition

Diagnosis:

D-dimer measurement: If normal, no indication for further investigation but if raised, a duplex ultrasound examination of the deep veins should be performed.

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of DVT (Filling defects in flow and lack of compressibility indicate the presence of a thrombosis)

Ascending venography shows thrombus as a filling defect, which is now rarely required

Treatment

  • Rest, elevation of the limb, and bandaging the entire limb with a crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presented to the emergency room with loss of consciousness, chest pain, and diaphoresis. On examination, she was grossly unstable and the bilateral pulses were unequal. ECG showed nonspecific ST-T changes. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation with acute onset chest pain, loss of consciousness and diaphoresis with bilaterally unequal pulses and ECG showing nonspecific ST-T changes is suggestive of aortic dissection, and as the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the next best investigation is transesophageal ECHO.

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. Predisposing factors include mainly age, hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and pregnancy. The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Contrast-enhanced CT(CECT) is currently the most preferred imaging modality for aortic dissection. A double-lumen aorta is seen on CECT. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred for patients who are unstable for transportation.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system, which uses the location of the proximal tear alone.

The classification and management of aortic dissection is explained in the images given below.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute pancreatitis is_______
questions.solution:
• Contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.

The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

questions.text: The investigation of choice for localizing the cause in a patient presenting with nasal discharge following a skateboarding accident, which has the following appearance on a tissue paper is:
questions.solution:
The image showing double target sign on tissue paper and the history is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea. HRCT is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in CSF rhinorrhea.

Though Beta 2-transferrin assay is the best laboratory test for identifying the presence of CSF in the sinonasal fluid it does not provide information regarding the site or laterality of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.
  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

Note: Reservoir sign is also seen in acute mastoiditis/ coalescent mastoiditis where mastoid acts as a reservoir of pus and pus reappear in EAC immediately after cleaning.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman came with complaints of headache for 1 month. She also reports aching of the jaw during her meals. Over the last week, she has experienced episodes of painless visual loss which lasts for around 10 minutes. Which will be the best investigation for the diagnosis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis. The best investigation for the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is temporal artery biopsy.

Histopathology shows panarteritis with the presence of mononuclear cells and giant cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a first-degree relative with BRCA1 gene mutation, presented to the OPD with a normal mammography report. The next investigation of choice to evaluate for breast disease would be _______
questions.solution:
MRI is helpful in the screening of high-risk individuals, and it is the most sensitive imaging modality. However, it should be done after initial radiological evaluation, in which the results may be inconclusive.

Here, the patient is a high-risk individual since there is family history of first-degree relative with BRCA1 gene mutation and initial radiological evaluation is normal. Hence, MRI is the next step to evaluate further. Trucut biopsy is the next step following MRI.

American Cancer Society Risk Criteria for Breast Magnetic Resonance Imaging Screening:

Women at high lifetime risk (≈20%-25% or greater) of breast cancer

  • Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation

  • First-degree relative with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation, but have not had genetic testing themselves.

  • Radiation therapy to the chest between the ages of 10 and 30

  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome or Cowden syndrome or a first-degree relative with one of these syndromes

Women at moderately increased (15%-20%) lifetime risk

  • Lifetime risk of breast cancer of 15%-20% according to risk assessment tools based mainly on family history

  • Personal history of breast cancer, ductal carcinoma in situ, lobular carcinoma in situ, atypical ductal hyperplasia, or atypical lobular hyperplasia.

  • Extremely dense breasts or unevenly dense breasts when viewed by mammograms

questions.text: A young villager presents to the clinic with abdominal pain for the past 1 month. Personal history is notable for keeping goats and sheep in the home. On examination, you feel a firm mass in the right hypochondrium which moves with respiration. Blood investigations and serology is suggestive of the hepatic hydatid cyst. Which of the following will be the best investigation to assess the hydatid cyst in this person?
questions.solution:
Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa.

CT scan has an accuracy of 98% in the detection of hydatid cysts and higher sensitivity to demonstrate the daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts. 
The indirect hemagglutination test and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have a sensitivity of 80% overall and are the initial screening tests of choice.

Hydatid cysts in CT scan with collapsed /detached membrane:

Note:

  • First/Initial imaging test: USG
  • Best imaging test: CT scan

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is defined as inflammation of brain parenchyma caused by the herpes virus, and it typically presents as an acute febrile illness.

Patients typically present with acute onset of fever, altered levels of consciousness, personality changes, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms, especially in the temporal lobe. Focal or generalized seizures occur in many patients with HSV encephalitis. Other most commonly encountered focal findings include aphasia, ataxia, upper motor neuron or lower motor neuron type lesions, and cranial nerve deficits.

HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. Other investigations that can help include CSF examination, CSF culture, serological studies, MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

The T2-weighted MRI of the brain will show hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.

The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction, avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures, and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in the treatment of HSV encephalitis.

 Other options:

Option A: IgM antibodies in CSF - Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

Option B: Tzanck smear of CSF - A positive smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and ground glass appearance. It is a rapid, inexpensive, and fairly sensitive diagnostic test. The Tzanck smear is typically used to diagnose cutaneous herpes infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. It is not an appropriate diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis, as it does not provide definitive confirmation of the presence of HSV in the CSF.

Option D: CSF culture in chick embryos - It is not a sensitive test used for the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis. Negative CSF viral cultures have no value in ruling out HSV encephalitis. Although this method can be used to isolate HSV, it is not as sensitive or specific as PCR for viral DNA and it can take a longer time to obtain results.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset breathlessness. He has undergone hip replacement one month back. As a physician, you are suspecting a pulmonary embolism. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for your diagnosis?

choices.text: Ventilation perfusion scanning (V/Q scan) of lungs

questions.solution:
CT chest with intravenous contrast is the investigation of choice for pulmonary embolism (PE).

Other options:

  • Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q ) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.
  • MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor ventilation perfusion scan can be done. 
  • Echocardiography is not a reliable diagnostic imaging tool for acute PE because most patients with PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

 

 

The arrows in the following images demonstrate a pulmonary embolus. Also the gross specimen image helps correlation.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with a photosensitive rash, arthralgias, and shortness of breath is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific for the diagnosis of SLE.

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age.  

Clinical and immunological manifestations of SLE:

  1. Skin
    • acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash)
    • chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus-like) 
  2. Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Synovitis involving ≥2 joints
  5. Serositis (pleurisy, pericarditis)
  6. Renal: 
    • Protein/Creatinine ratio >0.5
    • RBC casts
  7. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia
  11. Immunological manifestations
    • Antinuclear antibodies >reference value (positive in >98% patients)
    • Anti-dsDNA >reference value (specific)
    • Anti-Smith antibody (specific)
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (lupus anticoagulant, false-positive rapid plasma reagin)
    • Low serum complement

To diagnose SLE, at least 4 out of 11 of the above criteria must be positive. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive then four criteria are not required. 

Antinuclear antibody detection is sensitive for the screening of SLE but not specific to diagnose it.

questions.text: The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is _______
questions.solution:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis has been visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation.

Laparoscopy is also the investigation of choice in endometriosis.

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels are raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels are raised in peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopic agglutination test is used for diagnosis of Leptospirosis.

History of fever with liver(icterus) and kidney(hematuria) involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

Serotype-specific tests:  

  1. Microscopic agglutination test 
  2. Macroscopic agglutination test 

Regarding other options :

  • WIDAL test is used to screen for typhoid fever
  • Weil Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial fevers  
  • Paul Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

 Leptospirosis is an underreported disease and it is estimated to cause 48,600 deaths worldwide annually.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below which is the investigation of choice in distal bowel tumours.
questions.solution:
Enteroclysis, which is the investigation of choice in patients with small bowel tumors.

Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube.

Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging of the entire small intestine.

Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumors and is the investigation of choice, particularly for tumors located in the distal small bowel.

Advantages of enteroclysis:

  • The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus.
  • The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, the following can be visualized:
    • Mild strictures
    • Small sinus tracts and fistulas
    • Minimal extrinsic compressions
    • Skip lesions
    • Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
  • The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for:
questions.solution:
Dried blood spots are taken from the heel to diagnose inborn errors of metabolism. It uses the principle of tandem mass spectroscopy (TMS).

TMS employs 2 Mass Spectrometers in series to screen blood samples for the presence and to determine concentrations of various substances like amino acid, fatty acids, and other metabolites. The abnormalities in metabolite levels serve as the diagnostic indicator for various inborn errors of metabolism like: 

  • Phenylketonuria
  • Ethylmalonic encephalopathy
  • Glutaric acidemia 

DBS is also used to detect profound T-cell lymphopenia in patients suspected to have severe combined immunodeficiency.

questions.text:
In aiding the diagnosis of a patient with suspected pneumoperitoneum, what is the most sensitive imaging modality among the given options:

A. Erect chest x-ray PA view

B. Supine abdomen x-ray AP view

C. Abdomen x-ray with left lateral decubitus view 

D. Erect abdomen x-ray PA view 

E. Contrast-enhanced CT
questions.solution:
Contrast-enhanced CT is the most sensitive imaging modality used in the diagnosis of minimal or suspected pneumoperitoneum. Free air as less as 1 ml can be detected. Small pockets of air trapped in peritoneal recesses can also be detected. 

An erect chest x-ray is the next most sensitive investigation, and also the initial investigation carried out to diagnose pneumoperitoneum. Free air under the diaphragm, also known as the crescent sign is seen here and it can detect around 3-4 ml of free air in the abdomen. 

If the patient is unable to stand, then an abdomen x-ray with left lateral decubitus view is more sensitive than supine or erect abdominal films to detect pneumoperitoneum.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation for the condition shown in the following radiograph?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows flattening of the femoral head and degenerative changes associated with the avascular necrosis of femoral head. The most reliable investigation to diagnose avascular necrosis is MRI.

MRI allows identification of avascular necrosis of femoral head in earlier stages and also determine the exact stage and extent of the pathologic process.

The radiographic appearance of avascular necrosis of femoral head may show the following changes:

  • Sclerosis of the femoral head
  • Flattening or loss of sphericity of femoral head
  • Crescent sign- It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head
  • In severe stages, it may show femoral head collapse and arthritic changes in the joint

questions.text: Investigation of choice for evaluation of bronchogenic carcinoma is:
questions.solution:
• CT is the investigation of choice for evaluation and diagnosis of bronchogenic carcinoma.
  • MRI > CT is investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumor/ pan coast tumor.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumors to obtain tissue diagnosis.

questions.text: The clinical investigation of choice in a patient with hypertension and hypokalemia is
questions.solution:
The clinical situation provided is symptomatic of hyperaldosteronism.

In this case, the screening test of choice should be the concurrent measurement of plasma renin and aldosterone level with a subsequent calculation of the aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR).

Determination of the aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR)

  • Continue blood pressure medication (stop intake of spironolactone alone for 4 weeks)
  • Correct hypokalemia

ARR screen positive if

  • ARR > 750 pmol/L per ng/mL per hour
  • Aldosterone > 450 pmol/L

questions.solution:
Paul-Bunnell test is used to diagnose kissing disease (infectious mononucleosis) caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction in children?
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan.

Nuclear scans (e.g., MAG3 and diethylene-triamine-penta-acetic acid (DTPA)) have replaced intravenous pyelogram as the diagnostic modality of choice in UPJ obstruction. Delayed clearance of contrast or the radiotracer implies obstruction.

Option C: Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux.

questions.text: What is used to diagnose the condition given in the below image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows sharply demarcated hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches over the trunk, pointing to a likely diagnosis of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. A Wood's lamp is used to diagnose the condition. Lesions show a pale yellow fluorescence when examined under the lamp.

Tinea versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous). The site most commonly affected is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen (seborrheic areas).

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. Among the following, which is the most appropriate investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of jejunoileal atresia, and among the options CECT abdomen is the most appropriate investigation to diagnose the condition.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in proximal bowel atresia such as duodenal atresia whereas abdominal distension with bilious vomiting is more with distal small bowel atresia such as jejuno-ileal atresia. Jejuno-ileal atresia is the most GI atresia.

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction.

  • Jejunal/ileal atresia - Triple bubble appearance
  • Duodenal atresia - Double bubble appearance

A contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other bowel anomalies. 

 

In jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is possible. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis. 

Classification of Jejunoileal atresia:

Type

Feature

Type 1

Mucosal web or diaphragm

Type 2

With an atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery

Type 3 a

Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap

Type 3 b

An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap

Type 4

Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance

 

An erect X-ray of the abdomen showing ileal atresia. The image shows a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of ileal atresia.

questions.text: What is the most specific investigation of choice in bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
HRCT is the most specific investigation of choice in bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis is abnormal irreversible dilatation of bronchi. It is caused by the destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue due to complications from infections, congenital conditions or autoimmune disorders.

 HRCT findings in bronchiectasis

  • The signet ring sign is seen when the dilated bronchus and accompanying pulmonary artery branch are seen in cross-section. The bronchus and artery should be the same size, whereas, in bronchiectasis, the bronchus is 1.5 times the size of the adjacent vessel. (As shown in the CT scan below)
  • Tree-in-bud pattern seen due to thickened secretions.
  • Tram track sign is seen due to lack of peripheral tapering of the bronchus. 
  • String of beads appearance is seen as alternate dilatation and constriction in varicose bronchiectasis. 
  • Cluster of grapes appearance is seen as cysts emanating from the bronchial wall in cystic bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which of the following test is used to diagnose Meniere’s disease?
questions.solution:
The glycerol test is useful for the diagnosis of Meniere's disease

Glycerol is an osmotic diuretic which when given orally reduces hydrops and improves symptoms

Electrocochleography done along with a glycerol test (showing improvement after glycerol) is diagnostic of Meniere’s disease.

Other options

Oto acoustic emissions (OAE) are low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea that can be elicited by a sensitive microphone. OAEs are present when outer hair cells are healthy and are absent when they are damaged and thus help to test the function of cochlea. They do not disappear in VIIIth nerve pathology as cochlear hair cells are normal.

Caloric test though used in Meniere's disease is not diagnostic as it is abnormal in many other conditions like ototoxicity, vestibular schwannoma, vestibular neuritis, etc.

Dix Hallpike test is useful when a patient complains of vertigo in certain head positions. It also helps to differentiate a peripheral from a central lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best specimen to diagnose congenital cytomegalovirus infection?

choices.text: Specimen of an organ such as liver, kidney

questions.solution:
Congenital CMV infection is diagnosed by detection of virus in the saliva or urine (saliva > urine), within the first two weeks of life. 

Congenital CMV infection occurs when a pregnant woman passes the cytomegalovirus to her unborn child. CMV is a common virus belonging to the herpesvirus family.

Congenital CMV infection can occur when a pregnant woman is infected with CMV for the first time (primary infection) or when she experiences reactivation or reinfection with a different strain of the virus during pregnancy. The virus can be transmitted to the fetus through the placenta.

The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Investigations:

  • Diagnosis can be made by the presence of IgM antibodies in the fetal blood. Isolation of the virus from the urine or blood by PCR is more sensitive.
  • If culture is required then urine samples are better than saliva.
  • PCR assays can be used to detect small amounts of CMV DNA in the urine.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male smoker presented with painless hematuria. The investigation of choice is ____.
questions.solution: Painless gross hematuria in an elderly man is indicative of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). BPH is the most common cause of gross hematuria in the elderly. So, in this case, the investigation of choice is ultrasonography kidney-ureter-bladder (USG KUB).

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with itchy papules over face, neck and V area of chest for last 3 years which are exacerbated in summers and improved in winters. What test can be done to confirm diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history points towards Photoallergic Contact Dermatitis. Photopatch test is used to diagnose this.

  • Photoallergic contact dermatitis is a delayed-type IV hypersensitivity reaction and has a similar presentation to other forms of allergic contact dermatitis but with a predilection for photo exposed sites, particularly during the initial stages.
  • The dermatitis is localized to exposed areas of the skin, usually with well‐demarcated margins where the skin is covered by clothing, for example at the collar and ‘V’ of the neck, below the end of sleeves on the backs of the hands and on the ankles below the trouser legs. Photo allergic contact dermatitis spares the skin behind earlobe (Wilkinson’s triangle) since it is a photo-protected site.

Photopatch test: The main clinical indication includes the investigation of patients with eczematous rashes predominantly affecting light‐exposed sites and a history of worsening following sun exposure.

  • Application of the allergens is done similar to conventional patch tests, except that they must be applied in duplicate – one set is irradiated and the other (the control) is not. Usually, the two sets of tests are applied on either side of the vertebral column at the same level.
  • A positive reaction on the irradiated side only is an indication of photoallergy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presented with low-grade fever, cough, night sweats, and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. In view of TB investigations, the Mantoux test was negative, chest X-ray showed non-specific findings and an adequate amount of sputum could not be collected for slide examination. Which of the following is used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
The test used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient is the Interferon-gamma release assay(IGRA).

TB test done on a whole blood sample is IGRA. In this test, sensitized T lymphocytes (from whole blood) of suspected individuals, are exposed to highly specific M. tuberculosis antigens such as CFP –10 and ESAT 6. This releases the cytokine IFN- gamma into the blood, which is then measured. It has been evaluated for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in HIV patients (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test.

 IGRAs that have been approved by the US (FDA) are

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube test (QFT-GIT): It quantitates the amount of interferon-gamma produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • T-SPOT.TB test (T-Spot): It determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing Interferon-gamma.
  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus)

IGRAs are more specific than Tuberculin Skin Testing (TST) because of less cross-reactivity to BCG vaccination and sensitization by nontuberculous mycobacteria.

There are 3 described methods for tuberculin skin testing (TST):

  • Mantoux test, also known as the Pirquet test (preferred method)
  • Heaf test
  • Tine test

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB and resistance to rifampicin in one hour. This test uses a sputum sample and only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required.

Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis. Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in the mycobacterial cell wall, released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis. Urine LAM is a useful tool in diagnosing tuberculosis, especially in patients with HIV and a low CD 4 count. 

QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T cell responses to TB specific antigens.
